isis.stitle: VT-365 Diesel Engine Diagnostics (2002) - ENGINE SYMPTOMS DIAGNOSTICS - Test Procedures - Combustion Leaks to Coolant

svcprocinfo.para: Combustion leaks can be identified by combustion gas observed in engine coolant deaeration tank. The most probable cause of combustion gas leakage to the cooling system is past injector or glow plug sleeve in the cylinder head. A failed head gasket or porous cylinder wall is possible, but should not be suspected unless evidence of engine overheating or high engine mileage without proper coolant conditioning.

svcsubproc.title: Combustion Leakage Test using Low Pressure

step1.para: Plug in cylinder block heater to warm coolant.

warning.para: To avoid serious personal injury or possible death, use only the following procedure to remove the pressure type cap from the cooling system. Always allow the engine to cool first. Wrap a thick, heavy cloth around the cap. Loosen cap slowly; then pause a moment. This will avoid possible scalding by hot coolant or steam. Continue to turn cap to the left and remove.

step1.para: Install radiator pressure tester with appropriate adapter.
Pressurize cooling system to 96 kPa (14 psi).
Remove glow plug harnesses and glow plugs for all cylinders.
Clean glow plug sleeves with cotton swabs.

figure.caption: Cutaway of Cylinder Head Showing Glow Plug Sleeve

step1.para: Verify that cooling system is still pressurized at 96 kPa (14 psi).
Bar engine over by hand and check for coolant flooding the top of piston and flowing out glow plug sleeve bore.

item.para: If leak is slight, pressure may have to be left on overnight and inspect cooling system for leakage in morning. Leave cylinder block heater plugged in.
If leak is found, go to step 8.
If no leakage is found, proceed to Combustion Leakage Test using High Pressure procedures.

figure.caption: Cutaway of Cylinder Head Showing Injector Sleeve

step1.para: Remove cylinder head from engine as described in the Engine Service Manual. Perform all inspections and pressure test cylinder head to verify leak path. Inspect cylinder head gasket for coolant leaks and verify crankcase and cylinder head surface flatness using a straight edge and feeler gauge.

item.para: It is recommended to replace both the injector and glow plug sleeves for a cylinder that shows combustion leakage.

step1.para: If the injector and glow plug sleeves were replaced, retest the cylinder head with pressure test plate to verify repair.
Return coolant to operating level in the deaeration tank.

svcsubproc.title: Combustion Leakage Test using High Pressure

step1.para: Plug in cylinder block heater to warm coolant.
Remove glow plug harnesses and glow plugs for all cylinders.

warning.para: To avoid serious personal injury or possible death, use only the following procedure to remove the pressure type cap from the cooling system. Always allow the engine to cool first. Wrap a thick, heavy cloth around the cap. Loosen cap slowly; then pause a moment. This will avoid possible scalding by hot coolant or steam. Continue to turn cap to the left and remove.

step1.para: Remove cap (or radiator pressure tester) from deaeration tank and fill tank with coolant to a point above the deaeration inlet line to tank.
Install the compression adapter in the glow plug bore and adapt gauge end to accept shop air pressure 690-1100 kPa (100-160 psi).

note.para: Verify that O-ring is on compression adapter when installed and removed from glow plug bore.

warning.para: To avoid serious personal injury, possible death, or damage to the engine, be aware that engine may rotate sharply when cylinder is pressurized.

step1.para: With shop air applied, bar engine over so that valves are shut on cylinder to be tested.
Observe deaeration tank for escaping air. If there is a leak in the pressurized cylinder, bubbles of air will be seen in the deaeration tank.

note.para: Pressurize each cylinder for a minimum of 3 minutes to ensure leaking air can arrive at deaeration tank

item.para: If leak is found, go to step 7.

If no leak is found, remove each cylinder head one at a time following the procedures described in the Engine Service Manual. Do all inspections and pressure test cylinder head to verify leak path. Inspect cylinder head gasket for coolant leaks and verify crankcase and cylinder head surface flatness using a straight edge and feeler gauge.
If cylinder head leak is found, repair as necessary and retest to confirm repair.
If no leak is found, inspect cylinder bores.

step1.para: Remove cylinder head from engine as described in the Engine Service Manual. Perform all inspections and pressure test cylinder head to verify leak path. Inspect cylinder head gasket for coolant leaks and verify crankcase and cylinder head surface flatness using a straight edge and feeler gauge.

item.para: It is recommended to replace both the injector and glow plug sleeves for a cylinder that shows combustion leakage.

step1.para: If the injector and glow plug sleeves were replaced, retest the cylinder head with pressure test plate to verify repair.
Return coolant to operating level in the deaeration tank.
